description.narrative:
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Center for Civilian in Conflict (CIVIC) is an international organization based in Washington DC that works to increase the protection of civilians in conflict. Based on CIVIC's own investigations of how conflicts affect civilians, the organization plans various efforts to ensure that military actors and peacekeeping forces in different ways protect civilian in a better way. CIVIC provides technical support, training and engage in advocacy primarily targeting military actors at national and international level. CIVIC began working in Afghanistan about 15 years ago and the organization has since grown. Today, CIVIC works mainly in Afghanistan, Iraq, Nigeria and Ukraine, as well as with several peace missions such as the one’s in South Sudan, Mali, DRC and Somalia. CIVIC also engage in advocacy to influence international organizations such as the UN, AU, NATO, the EU and the United States to develop their efforts to protect civilians. Since certain aspects of the work against NATO and the US could fall outside the OECD/DAC definition of official development cooperation (ODA), Sida has made clear in the agreement that Sida does not finance this kind of effort.
CIVIC has applied for SEK 15,000,000 from Sida which they intend to use to expand their work to more conflict areas as well as deepen their thematic skills in gender equality and performance monitoring. CIVIC will be a new partner for Sida and the support will be given in the form of core support.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Center for Civilians in Conflict (CIVIC) är en internationell organisation baserad i Washington DC som arbetar med att öka skyddet av civila i konflikt. Baserat på CIVIC's egna undersökningar av hur civila drabbas av konflikter utformar organisationen olika insatser för att militära aktörer och fredsbevarande styrkor på olika vis ska skydda civila på ett bättre sätt. CIVIC ger tekniskt stöd, tränar och utövar påtryckningsarbete mot främst militära aktörer på nationell och internationell nivå. CIVIC började att arbeta i Afghanistan för cirka 15 år sedan och organisationen har sedan växt. Idag arbetar CIVIC i huvudsak i Afghanistan, Irak, Nigeria och Ukraina samt med flera fredsmissioner så som i Sydsudan, Mali, DRK och Somalia. CIVIC försöker även påverka internationella organisationer som FN, AU, NATO, EU samt USA att utveckla sitt arbete med att skydda civila. Eftersom vissa delar av arbetet mot NATO och USA skulle kunna falla utanför OECD/DAC:s definition av officiellt utvecklingssamarbete (ODA) har Sida tydliggjort i avtalet att Sida inte finansierar denna typ av insatser.
CIVIC har ansökt om SEK 15 000 000 från Sida vilka de ämnar använda till att utöka sitt arbete till fler konfliktområden samt fördjupa sin tematiska kompetens inom jämställdhet och resultatuppföljning. CIVIC blir en ny partner för Sida och stödet kommer att ges i form av kärnstöd.

description.narrative: 2019 represented a year of consolidation in relation to CIVIC's organisational growth and special efforts were made to create and implement standard operating procedures, with particular focus on understanding the gaps in policies and processes across the organisation, especially between field offices and headquarters. CIVIC has reported many relevant and important achievements in 2019, of which a few are accounted for below: - In 2019, CIVIC continued to push for reforms within the UN peacekeeping structure in order to improve protection options for civilians. CIVIC successfully influenced the mandates of the peacekeeping missions in CAR, DRC, Soth Sudan and Mali. For example, CIVIC secured significant changes to the protection of civilians (POC) language in MINUSMA's (Mali) mandate when it was renewed in June. As a result, POC is a higher priority and the resolution has the most detailed language on civilian harm mitigation (CHM) of any peacekeeping operation mandate. CIVIC also specifically raised awareness on the critical role of strategic planners in peacekeeping missions. For example, in anticipation of the risk for budget cuts of the UN peacekeeping mission in CAR, CIVIC managed to mobilise Secretariat personnel to work to mitigate such risk. - CIVIC's work with civilian protection groups deepened and expanded in 2019. All community-based protection efforts reported positive outcomes in 2019, of which those in Nigeria and Afghanistan are the best documented. For example, as a result of interaction and dialogue between community protection groups and the military related to reintegration of former Boko Haram fighters in Bama in Nigeria, the reintegration process is now more inclusive which helps improve community buy-in for returnees. Community based activities also started in Iraq and Yemen during the year. - In 2019, there was also positive progress in relation to Civilian Harm Mitigation (CHM). For instance, CHM was institutionalized into the curricula of three Nigerian military educational institutions and 2,487 armed actors, members of the military, and other security force members were trained in Nigeria. - In Afghanistan, Nangarhar community members successfully negotiated with a local Taliban commander in the Nayzan district to halt the planting of new improvised explosive devices (IEDs) along public roads and to refrain from using civilian homes and properties as bases of operations for staged attacks against the national defense and security forces. During 2019, CIVIC also developed guidelines for future single-gender community working group sessions in Afghanistan, in order to allow women to discuss protection issues that may be too sensitive to bring up in front of male counterparts.
